Why does that have to be the plan? It is serving a useful function and mission. Why not let it continue to be eyes on the galaxy and solar system? Right now the telescope has an orbit at about 356 miles or so. What would be the technology needed or problems encountered in making this telescope a part of the International Space Station (ISS)? It seems to me that it could be easily adapted for station use.

content: There is a bigger and better space telescope they are going to place farther out in to space. By then the technology on Hubble will be so old and too expensive to keep going. The Hubble which started out to be a complete flop has turned into one the best projects we have ever done and have learned allot from it. I guess it's like anything else in our throw away society. Like they old tube TVs you got laying around, would you pay to have them fixed or replace the tube on it if you could even find it? All about money. Who knows, they may find another use for Hubble by then and if it is still functioning continue to use it. But the overall program is due to expire. "The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is intended to replace the ageing Hubble telescope. It will be larger than its predecessor, sit farther from Earth and have a giant mirror to enable it to see more. Officials said the JWST - named after a former Nasa administrator - was on course for launch in June 2013. The full-scale model is being displayed outside the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum in the US capital, Washington DC. It was recently shown off in Seattle at the American Astronomical Society meeting." Hubble has managed to allow the science community to date our universe to 13.7 billions years old. Before Hubble, they guessed anywhere from 10 to 19 or 20 billion years. With Webb, we may even see the beginning of time as we know it (if that's possible, but they say it is.) Mind blowing at the very least. Ref. "http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/6645179.stm"
